Okay. Just for your information, the Agena was very stable, we are having no noticeable oscillations at all.
A FLASHBULB pops. Morse takes a photo of Janet and Rick, paper Gemini and Agena now GLUED TOGETHER over earth.
Congratulations, Mrs. Armstrong. A great day for the United States. Ed walks up with a PLATE OF FOOD for Janet. She hesitates
You can’t fast the whole three days. A beat. Then, as she takes the plate...
We’re about to have LOS, but I have some dope for you to follow...
Dave grabs a pen, takes notes as Lovell continues.
CSQ will pick you up on the other.. But the Comms turn STATIC as they lose signal. Dave drops pen, sees Neil’s pulled out two PACKETS. DAY 1, MEAL B.
No thanks, I want to prep the E.V.A.
We should eat. It’s an order. Neil holds a packet up to a nozzle on the console, injects it with water. It looks pretty bad.
I think there’s some air bubbles. Neil tosses it to Dave, who spins it around, then leaves
I’m gonna let it breathe.  71. Dave grabs the EVA manual, glances at the console... PAUS
..-Neil, we’re in a bank. Neil turns. CLOSE ON the 8 ball, showing a 30 degree roll
None of our thrusters are on, NEIL it must be the -- Cut the Agena’s thrusters. Dave quickly follows orders. Neil WATCHES the 8 ball...
Stabilizing... Reactivating OAMS, reorienting to correct position. Neil hits the Gemini's thrusters, but the ship LURCHES, s SPINNING. Dave GRUNTS. Neil’s eyes TICK to the console.
Okay, let’s shut everything down. They shut everything off, but the ship KEEPS SPINNING ON AXIS. Food, checklists, charts start FLYING about the CAB

A few more minutes, we’ve just about got it sorted. GUS (INTO COMMS) Shit, we’re gonna be here all night. ED (INTO COMMS, to Roger) He’1l turn the corner. In half an hour he’1l be singing Sinatra. GUS (INTO COMMS, to Ed) Stop screwing around, wouldya?  97.
Easy, everyone just cool it. GUS (INTO COMMS) Get the damn comms working and we'll cool it.
I got a surge in the AC Bus 2 LAUNCH DIRECTOR (COMMS) Voltage. Try resetting the meter. Gus, happy to have something to do, looks over the gauges
Rog, you see anything on the dials? Chaffee turns to look and notices a SMALL FLAME on the fl Before he can react... the flame JUMPS.

Hey! The flame FLASHES through the cockpit, FIRE BLAZING aroun three of them. Ed and Gus react -- it’s frighting, but th stay CALM, HUSTLING through evacuation procedures... Ed reaches for the hatch... the latches are TIGHT. He gra ratchet, STRUGGLES to loosen a latch, but his arm is ENGU by fire. He KEEPS WORKING... even as his suit starts to M Ed GRIMACES. The latch isn’t budging. His eyes DART to th other five latches. As he starts to PANIC, SMASH TO --
A FAR VIEW of the CAPSULE from 400 feet below. It looks f
Gus? Can you hear us up there? LAUNCH DIRECTOR ROCCO PETRONE, 40, eyes the capsule on th MONITOR. We’re in a makeshift LAUNCH COMMAND at the base the rocket. Deke walks up with a cup of coffee.
Comms are still out?
Should have been fixed by now. The tech at the comms shrugs. Petrone tries again.
Gus, can you hear -- ED (COMMS) We got a fire in the cockpit!  98. Petrone pauses, eyes the monitor... as the hatch window L UP, turning WHITE. Deke remains calm.
Okay. Get them out of there.
Hey crew, can you egress at this time? Confirm it. No response. Deke takes the Comms.
Guenter, get in there and help them. Deke looks up. High above, techs move towards the capsule

Crew did we get verification? CHAFFEE (COMMS) Can you egress at -- We have a bad fire! We’re burning up! We’re burning... They hear Chaffee SCREAM. It’s PRIMAL, HEART-STOPPING. De now CONCERNED, looks up. A beat, then -- BOOM!!! The capsule RUPTURES, SMOKE POURING OUT... Everyone in the blockhouse PALES. Deke and Petrone stare, incredulous as the techs above fall back.
Pad leader, are you able to GUENTER WENDT (COMMS) hear them? Guenter -- All the smoke, we can’t... Deke, UNNERVED, takes the comms, tries to remain professi
Gus, can you hear us? Gus? But there's NO RESPONSE. Off Deke --
Janet reads, Rick and Mark play on floor. A quiet moment. until the phone RINGS. Janet stands, picks up the phone.
Hello?
Janet, it’s Deke. There’s been an accident at the Cape. We... we don’t know how bad yet. Would you mind going over to Pat’s?  99. Off Janet, PALE, SMASH TO --
The kids play as Janet helps Pat carry in grocery bags.
Thank goodness you swung by, I'd have a car full of melted ice pops. Pat smiles, chipper, when the doorbell RINGS.
You mind tossing the rest of the perishables into the fridge?
Of course not. Pat exits. Janet puts the milk in the fridge... when she hears an AWFUL, GUT WRENCHING, ANIMALISTIC SCREAM. Jan freezes. As the sound RIPPLES through her, SMASH TO -
Neil as we left him, on his bed, tux still on, watching T And waiting. A beat. Then the phone RINGS. Neil grabs it.
Hello?
Neil.
Hey. How'd it go?
(pause) Not great, there was... an accident. No easy way to say this... Ed, Gus and Roger, they’re, they’re gone. Neil sits there. Blinks. Not following.
I don’t understand. It was a test.
We think there was a wiring issue.
I don’t... I don’t follow.  100.

There was a fire and, and we'll get to the bottom of it. Right now we need you guys to lay low. The press is all over this, Senator Mondale’s going to call for an investigation, we don’t want you to have to deal with any of that, okay? Neil?

Yes. Okay. Thanks. Neil hangs up. A beat. Neil sits, silent. Blank. He lifts the phone, as if to make a call... and holds the receiver dial tone PULSING, growing LOUDER, until... ..-he SMASHES the receiver on the cradle. Again. And again. And AGAIN. Harder now. Until he’s smashing the receiver on the cradl with such FORCE... ...that the phone CRACKS... the nightstand BUCKLES. And still he continues. Pain and rage pouring out... He keeps POUNDING the phone... UNTIL it’s PULVERIZED... U the nightstand SPLITS... UNTIL his fingers, his hand star BLEED... UNTIL at last he runs out of steam. And pauses. PANTING. His face contorted... his eyes TICKI to his hand. BADLY MAULED, blood DRIPPING down the phone. We hold on him for an awful beat and then we... FADE TO BLACK.

location: ELLINGTON AIR FORCE BASE, HOUSTON, TX

text: TIGHT ON NEIL’S FACE. Eyes focused, but EMOTIONLESS. DEAD A stark contrast to the jagged hand-held camera. And a st contrast to the Neil we last saw. Wounds buried, yet ther the surface. Scar tissue, invisible to most, less so to u Ellington Air Force Base May 6, 1968  101.

Winds are pretty rough today, keep an eye on your translation rates. PULL BACK to find Neil exposed to the elements, strapped THE LUNAR LANDING TEST VEHICLE. A MESS of METAL PIPES wit COCKPIT. The realization of the DIAGRAMS we saw on P.101.

Approaching altitude, drifting east. NEIL (INTO COMMS) Copy. Correcting. Neil hits the thruster and a BURST of peroxide spits out our right. As it pushes the LLTV left we PULL BACK FURTHE Neil’s HUNDREDS OF FEET ABOVE THE GROUND in a contraption doesn’t look like it should fly. Jesus. The camera does a WILD 360 around the belching craft then... PUSHES IN on N

Five hundred feet. Switching to lunar mode and starting descent. Dead-eyed, but alert, Neil hits a button and starts to gu the LLTV to a landing. Thrusters POP and HISS; the craft ROCKS and BUCKS, but Neil’s eyes REMAIN STEADY on his gau CLOSE ON the ALTITUDE GAUGE: 400... 300... 200 feet.
Final landing approach. Neil calmly pilots the LLTV down through 100 feet... When bottom FALLS OUT. The craft starts to DROP RAPIDLY. Neil PULLS on the thruster, but the LLTV doesn't respond.
Increase altitude! Neil! Neil HITS the thrusters again... The craft SHOOTS UP to 2 feet... then ROLLS SHARPLY TO THE RIGHT!! It’s terrifying

Attitude control degrading. Steam SPITS from the thrusters; peroxide particles burn N neck. UNFAZED, he tries to correct the roll... only to ha the craft go UP_ON IT’S SIDE LIKE A CARNIVAL RIDE! Neil quickly PULLS the throttle right, but now the LLTV S

head_text.subj: BACK EVEN FURTHER ON THE OTHER SIDE

text: Your translation rates are too high! You’ve gotta bail out! Neil, do you hear me, you have to bail out now! But Neil, eyes DARK, barely registers this. Lovell’s voic FADES... then THE SOUND DROPS OUT ENTIRELY. PUSH IN TIGHT ON NEIL’S FACE IN TOTAL SILENCE. We clock the INTENSITY, HARD and COLD, the DARKNESS in hi eyes... MORE FRIGHTENING than anything happening around h A long beat... then Neil’s eyes TICK DOWN. We see the ground RUSHING UP to meet the craft.

I gotta go. LIGHTENING FAST Neil PULLS the ejection handle. BOOM!!! SOUND COMES RUSHING BACK as the Ejection Seat EXPLODES ou the LLTV, TOSSING Neil a hundred feet up into the air!!! POP POP POP! Neil’s parachute unfurls, stabilizing us jus time to see the LLTV CRASH below... and BURST INTO FLAMES Off Neil, staring down at the FIERY BLAZE OF METAL, PRELA
The vehicle is not safe. EXT./INT. DEKE’S OFFICE, MSC, HOUSTON - NIGHT
Kraft and Deke argue with Neil.
We need to shut it down, Neil.
It’s the best simulation we have.
Yes, but --
Landing in lunar gravity is the most substantial hurdle left; the vehicle gives us the best approximation of flight in a lunar environment.  103.
Okay, but you and the others are too valuable to risk on a fly by wire system with no backup.
The ejection seat is the backup.
Neil, the political fallout NEIL from another accident -- That’s what you’re worried about?
You could have died, Neil. NEIL But I didn’t.
A split second more and -- NEIL We need to fail! Deke REACTS, but Neil’s too far gone to notice...

That’s the point. These tests aren’t about getting it right, they’re about knowledge. We fail and we learn and we fail and we learn and it’s the only goddamn reason we've gotten this far. We have to keep failing here so we don’t fail there.
But at what cost?
Whatever it takes. the tense standoff, we PRELAP --
.-.the NASA press release said the ejection took place at 200 feet...
Janet stands by the stove, cooking. Or rather she was. No she LISTENS to the radio on the sill. PALE.

.--but eyewitnesses said Armstrong was much lower. Senator Mondale was particularly vocal on the loss of the multi-million dollar machine...  104. The door opens. Neil walks in, sees dinner isn’t on the table, starts to head towards his office when...
Are you okay? Neil stops, turns. IMPENETRABLE.
It’s always a sad day when you lose a machine. It’s hard to take; Janet needs more, but Neil’s distracte His eyes TICK to the radio.

...we’ve spent more than we did on the Manhattan project, we’ve put our most talented young men at risk, and what are the odds of success? Neil STIFFENS. Janet, visibly upset, turns back to the st The radio seems to grow LOUDER.
Is it any wonder that a majority of the public no longer feel the space program is worth it? The front door SLAMS. Janet turns. Neil’s gone. INT. WOLFIE’S RESTAURANT, CAPE KENNEDY - DAY

A 60's diner. Neil eats alone, studying data from his LLT crash. He jots down a note and takes a bite of steak whic he’s cut into CUBES (so he can eat while he works). Neil’s so engrossed, he doesn’t hear THE MUSIC. Hendrix. Along the Watchtower. As it rolls past him, we RACK FOCUS a table of YOUNG HIPPIES. Facial hair, tie-dye, a box rad A GIRL in Joplin sunglasses (think Penny Lane) STARES at His cut up steak. His close cropped hair. His thin black tie. He’s a walking ANACHRONISM. The girl points. The others SNICKER. Neil doesn’t notice. PUSH IN on him, OBLIVIOUS. A man alone, out of time, but nonetheless hell bent, single minded, DETERMINED. His eye TICKING insistently, his focus UNWAVERING. That is, until A FILE is dropped in front of Neil. CONFIDENTIAL. Neil lo up, finds Deke. Who sits, nods at the file. Neil opens it  105. GRAINY PHOTOGRAPHS of a HUGE ROCKET. With RUSSIAN MARKING
It was unmanned. 2 million pounds of thrust. It circled the moon. Dammit.
How long until we test the first stage of Saturn Five?
Public support for Apollo has been dropping like a brick since the fire, Congress won’t fund us to be second best. Shit, we move too slow, they won’t fund us at all. Neil REALIZES...
We're testing all 3 stages at once. Deke nods. Holy shit. Even Neil is struck.

Apollo 8 will attempt to duplicate what the Soviets did. Lovell’s in command. You’re the backup. Kraft may not have been impressed by your tirade, but Gilruth was. At least my version of it. (standing) Get the new LLTV online asap. You, Conrad and Borman’1l rotate. If we actually manage to get there, one of you is gonna have to land. Deke leaves. Neil processes. He’s one of three men who mi land on the moon. Jesus. A beat, then we PULL BACK... HIGH AND WIDE on the DINER. The Hendrix, the hippies and anonymous astronaut... who very well might make history. We take in the oddity of the tableau, then CUT TO --
A crane lifts the ENORMOUS SECOND STAGE of a SATURN ROCKE We're in the 8-acre, 526-foot-tall hanger that is the V.A

Jesus, that’s a big mother.  106. MIKE COLLINS (38, shrewd) stands with Neil, Buzz, Lovell, and a few others as the crane sets the second stage atop first, which sits on the massive APOLLO CRAWLER-TRANSPORT
Gonna be some kind of explosion if it goes up. (off the others) The MPAD guys said there’s a twenty percent chance.
I’m gonna get some water. Lovell, a little pale, heads off towards the office.
Shit, Buzz, he’s gotta fly that thing.
It’s in the briefing pack. Dave turns towards Neil, surprised. And a bit AGITATED.
You don’t think that’s a problem? This is exactly the kinda rush job that led to the fire. Neil doesn’t respond. Dave, annoyed, walks off after Love
He’s just pissed off cause he lost the lunar lottery.
What? What are you talking about?
The LLTV rotation. The LLTV’s unstable, the only guys they’1l risk on it are the ones who actually might land. 3 commanders, 2 pilots. Neil doesn’t like this talk; neither do the others.
You think you’re going to the moon?
The landing’s been up for grabs ever since Gus and Ed died. (MORE )

If 8 makes it there and back, 10, 11 or 12 is going to be the one. That’s Borman, Conrad or Neil. With Anders or me piloting. (off their reaction) What? I’m just saying what you're all thinking out loud.
Maybe you shouldn't. It's SHARP. Buzz turns, surprised. Before he can respond, the men see Lovell WAVING from the office. SMASH TO --
CLOSE ON a RADIO CONSOLE. We hear COMMS. IN RUSSIAN.
Activated, activated. GROUND (RUSSIAN, ON RADIO) Understood. Our comrades recommend a deep breath. Neil and the others join Lovell and Deke at the console. MILITARY AIDE/TRANSLATOR, 20s, explains.
The Japanese picked up the radio signal. A telemetry antenna and one of the solar arrays failed.
Bad maiden run for the Soyuz.
Orientation problems persist. (off the comms) He’s mid-retrofire.
One wing, no telemetry, how’s he managing re-entry?
This is his third attempt.
Jesus. It's good news for our team. But no one’s smiling.
Entering atmosphere... unable GROUND (RUSSIAN, ON RADIO) to control attitude... Center of gravity is off, you’re coming down too fast.  108. The men clock Komarov’s tone.
What’s happening? MILITARY TRANSLATOR The Soyuz’s attitude is off, it’s not getting any lift.
Nothing I lay my hands on GROUND (RUSSIAN, ON RADIO) works! Rubin, this is Zarya, deploy your drogue to slow descent!
He's deploying parachutes. DAVE SCOTT He’s gotta be coming in hot. They LEAN IN, the human element superseding the competiti
Main parachute has fail... GROUND (RUSSIAN, ON RADIO) Didn’t get that. Can you re--
Main parachute has fail... manually deploying reserve chute!
His main chute failed. LOVELL He’s got to have a reserve. They listen, TENSE... then Komarov starts to SCREAM.
The release failed! The release... STATIC. The astronauts BLANCH.
Rubin, this is Zarya, how do you hear me? Rubin, do you hear me? A beat. Nothing but STATIC on the radio.
I... I think he’s crashed. The men look down. GRIM. All save for Neil. Who heads out
Where are you going?
More of a head start now. We should make use of it.  109. He exits. Off Dave, STUNNED, we CUT TO --
COLOR FOOTAGE of ABC SCIENCE EDITOR JULES BERGMAN at the APOLLO 8 towering on the launch pad in the distance.
Good morning, I’m ABC Science Editor Jules Bergman at Cape Kennedy with a late status report on Apollo 8...
The broadcast continues but we’re now on the scene. Bergm sits at a desk in front of an ABC camera crew.

..-Astronauts Borman, Lovell and Anders are in their command module, the first manned spacecraft to leave Earth’s orbit... The camera starts MOVING, PUSHING PAST Bergman to a HUGE OF HUMANITY; Apollo posters, bell bottoms, Sgt. Pepper... Woodstock for geeks. In the middle of it all, a NASA VAN rolls from the launch pad towards mission control. CUT IN

Neil, Buzz and Fred Haise, the Apollo 8 backups, sit in b Buzz stares out the window, riveted, focusing on... PROTESTORS. We note the banners: Is space more important our poor? Our boys in Vietnam? Buzz sees the ANGER.
Nuts. Just nuts, huh? Buzz turns to Neil, reading a manual. COMPLETELY OBLIVIOU Off Buzz, clearly not understanding Neil at all, we CUT T

location: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, LAUNCH CONTROL CENTER

text: CLOSE ON Neil's eyes, now staring through the ENORMOUS WI of Launch Control at Apollo 8, steaming on the pad. In th b/g, the launch director runs through flight checks. Even at a distance, the Saturn is HUGE. And at 7.5 millio pounds of thrust, it’s the most powerful rocket in histor
T minus 1 minute.  110. As the flight crew sounds off, Deke joins Neil and looks the line.... at Dave’s jaw tensing, at Buzz scratching at neck, at Mike biting a nail... and then at Neil. Still.
Final go, no go. EECOM? EECOM ENGINEER I’m go. Launch commit. The whole room QUIETS as the call continues.
T minus ten, nine, eight, seven, main engine start... We SEE the engines FIRE before we HEAR them... Lights and ceiling tiles begin to SHAKE. A couple come CRASHING DOWN

Four, three, two, one, ignition... We hear the engines ROAR. A TSUNAMI OF THUNDER SLAMS into windows, BUCKLING the big one in front of Neil. Holy Shit A number of men HIT THE DECK. Even Neil FLINCHES... But the window HOLDS. And Apollo 8 lifts off the pad. There's something TERRIFYING about the POWER of the big rocket, the SPEED at which it hurtles into the sky... ..-but as it continues to rise, there’s scattered CLAPPIN the launch is successful. And momentarily, everyone start CHEER. Everyone, that is, but Neil. Who heads for the doo Off Deke, CLOCKING THIS, we CUT TO --
CLOSE ON Neil washing his hands. Concentrating. Methodica
Helluva launch. Neil looks up. Deke’s walked in. Neil shrugs, turns back the sink. Deke looks at him for a moment. Scrutinizing hi

I talked with Chris and Bob about the schedule and we’d like you to command 11. Obviously, if 8 is successful, 11 or 12 will probably be our first attempt at a landing. Neil nods, pleased, but doesn’t acknowledge the potential momentous nature of the mission.  111.
Who are you thinking for the crew?
Collins was cleared by the doc, he’s the best Command Module Pilot available. The Lunar Module Pilot, well, you could take Lovell, but it’s a quick turnaround. And he’s in line for his own command.
Who’s the other option?
Buzz is the guy with the most experience. Neil considers.
Let me have 24 hours.
Clock reads 9pm. Neil’s hunched over a preliminary traini schedule for Apollo 11.
You beat me to the moon I’m gonna kick your ass. Conrad, leaving, holds up a PACKET. Labeled APOLLO 12.
I hear Deke’s trying to stick you with Aldrin. Neil shrugs. Conrad shakes his head.
If you can survive 8 days with him in that sardine can, power to you...

Neil heads out. He starts to turn into the elevator bank he spots a LIGHT ON down the hall. Curious, he walks on.. ...and finds an open door. Inside, Buzz pours over a desk full of DIAGRAMS, EQUATIONS, TRAJECTORIES for the lunar landing. Buzz is so focused he doesn’t even notice Neil. Off Neil, standing, watching Buzz, PROCESSING, CUT TO --  112.

THREE MEN in GAS MASKS are led into a theater packed with reporters, pads and cameras ready. It’s ODD. Apollo 11, Pre-Flight Press Conference July 5, 1969 The men are led on stage to a TALL, THREE-SIDED PLASTIC B Fans are turned on to blow air TOWARDS THE AUDIENCE as th sit, take off the masks. It’s Neil, Mike Collins... and B Neil, STIFF, glances at Deke then walks to the podium.

We're here today to talk a bit about the forthcoming flight. We’re able to talk about it because of previous flights. Every flight took on new objectives and left us with very few additions to be completed. We’re grateful to those people who made it possible for us to sit here today. Neil sits, no trace of emotion. Deke takes the podium.
We'll take questions now. Jim?
(standing) Neil, when you learned you were going to command this flight, were you surprised? Overjoyed?
...I was pleased.
Okay, but how would you compare this feeling with winning an automobile? Or being selected as an astronaut?
(pause) I was pleased. The reporter isn’t pleased, but another jumps up.
Neil, were you aware that Ralph Abernathy is planning a protest for the day of the launch?  113.
No. I was not.
He said, and I quote, “A fifth of this nation lives in poverty. In the face of such suffering, space flight represents an inhuman priority.” Do you have any comment?
No. An awkward beat. Deke shoots Neil a look. fry harder.
Neil, if it does turn out, you’ll go down in history. What kind of thoughts do you have about that?
(making an effort) Several people have mentioned that. I hope that you and the public will recognize the thing as a group effort because it really is that.
But when a thought hits you; ‘Gosh, suppose that flight is successful’ --
I’m planning on it being successful. Why do you always say ‘suppose that flight will be successful?’
..-uh, I just meant, how you look at yourself as being part of history? Neil hesitates... and in that moment Buzz jumps in.

I think I can shed some light here. It’s a responsibility, but it’s exciting to be first. Even my wife is excited. She keeps slipping jewelry into my PPK. Some laughter. Neil looks ever so slightly IRRITATED.
You're planning to take some of her jewelry to the moon, Buzz?  114.
Well, sure. What fella wouldn’t want to give his wife bragging rights? Buzz smiles, enjoying the limelight.
Neil, will you take anything?

If I had a choice, I’d take more fuel. An awkward SILENCE. Then Mike LAUGHS. Reporters, relieved follow suit. But Neil doesn’t. Off Neil, UNCOMFORTABLE -- INT. NEIL AND JANET’S BEDROOM, ARMSTRONG HOUSE - NIGHT
CLOSE ON a SUITCASE. Very tidy. FIND Neil packing. Methodical. Emotionless. A beat, then Janet walks in.
Come say good night to the boys. Neil keeps packing. A beat, then Janet reaches over, CLOS the suitcase. Neil looks up at her.
The boys want you to tuck them in.
I gotta pack. He starts to turn back but she GRABS his arm. FORCEFUL.
I'd like you to talk to the boys.
(firm) I don’t have time.

Pat tried to commit suicide. Three days ago. Did you even know? She’s okay now. Okay as she’ll ever be. (then, off Neil) Everyday I pack your lunch, I make your dinner and I... I used to hope that someday I’d have something to show for it. I won’t. I know that now. And that’s fine. But Rick and Mark? What are the chances you’re coming back? 50 percent? 40? (MORE )
What are the chances it’s the last time they see you? (and then) You don’t have time? Make the fucking time. Off Neil, CUT TO --

location: MARK AND RICK'S BEDROOM, ARMSTRONG HOUSE

text: Rick (12) and Mark (6) both tucked in. Neil on Rick’s bed
So the trip is eight days?
Yes.
(explaining to Mark) They’1l1 be quarantined when they get back, to make sure they haven’t picked up any moon germs.
(worried) Are you scared, Daddy?
We've done everything before except for the actual landing.
(beat) But why do you have to go? Neil hesitates.
Because we have to demonstrate we can do this. Mark doesn’t know what to make of that. Rick tries to hel
Dad’s going to be famous.
You are? Neil doesn’t like the question any more than he did from reporters. He’s quiet. An AWKWARD BEAT. Jan steps in.  116.
Okay, it’s time for bed. Relieved, Neil leaves. HOLD ON Janet. ALONE.

WIDE on the house. A BLACK CAR idling by the curb. Neil comes to the door, duffel and a briefcase. He gives Janet perfunctory peck and walks to the car. ON JANET, watching as Neil hands off his duffel, gets in car and, without so much as a look back, shuts the door.

Neil sits back in his seat. He pulls out a mission briefi starts to read as the driver gets back in the car. The car pulls off. In that moment, the tension LEAVES Nei face. He looks out the window, at the houses slipping awa and we see imperceptible RELIEF. The mission has begun.

head_text.subj: EXIT. ASTRONAUT CREW QUARTERS, CAPE CANAVERAL

text: A large campus, a maze of one story barracks. Cape Canaveral, 4:20 AM, July 16, 1969 It's DARK, save for a light from one low window. And QUIE save for a MUFFLED THUMPING. THA-THUMP. THA-THUMP. The sound takes us through the lit window into --
CLOSE ON a STETHOSCOPE. FIND Neil, shirtless, in front of flight surgeon. We hear Neil’s heart rate SPEED UP. Neil’ eyes TICK to the Doc. Is he concerned? A long beat, then.
He’s clear. Send in Aldrin.
Neil sits beside an odd flower centerpiece, working his w through steak and eggs. Like it’s any other day.
What the hell are you doing? Deke eats breakfast with Neil and the two other astronaut He’s staring at Buzz, SIGNING multiple PHOTOS OF HIMSELF.  117.
Life insurance. Mine was denied. (passing them to Deke) Would you get these to Jean Ann? Mike reacts. Seriously? Unnerved, he glances at Neil, but Neil just keeps eating, totally unfazed.
Gentlemen. The men look up. Gilruth stands in the doorway, waiting. It’s time. As Neil stands, we CUT TO --

Deke leads the men into the ready room. Multiple techs sw around THREE ASTRONAUT SPACESUITS. 5:30 AM (Tf minus 4 hours, 3 minutes) As the men start to strip down, we see A SERIES of QUICK Tape SEALS up a DIAPER around a man’s waist. A MESH of LIQUID-COOLING TUBES are FILLED with water; a Z CLOSES the thin, nylon one-piece containing them. A ZIPPER CLOSES the internal pressure suit; a ‘SLIDE FAST ZIPS it shut; then a THERMAL SKIN is VELCROED on top of t METALLIC RINGS SNAP ON one glove, then another; SLEEVES a ROLLED over the rings. A COMMS (SNOOPY) CAP chin-strap is SNAPPED in place; its is PLUGGED INTO the top of the suit. An AIR NOZZLE is TWISTED ONTO the BLUE PORTAL on the fron a spacesuit; we hear the HISS of air as... A HELMET is PLACED on the head of a PRETERNATURALLY CALM The helmet SWIVELS into place and the sound FADES... ...we hear only the HISS OF OXYGEN as Neil CLOSES HIS EYE

location: GANTRY ELEVATOR, LAUNCH PAD 39A, CAPE CANAVERAL

text: CLOSE ON Neil, eyes still closed. The HISS of air pervade 6:45 AM (T minus 2 hours, 48 minutes)  118. Neil opens his eyes, takes in the ENORMOUS SATURN V ROCKE beside him. He rises quickly up its side on the high spee elevator with Buzz and Mike (suited up) and Deke. And we can’t help but notice the FLOCK OF PRESS VANS belo the HORDE OF MEDIA AND SPECTATORS stretching out before t

Guess we have a couple fans. Even Mike and Buzz find it STAGGERING. But for Neil it’s DEEPLY UNSETTLING. He looks away, eyes TICKING to the checklist on his wrist, FOCUSING on it as only he can... +..until the elevator JERKS to a halt.
Ready? Neil looks up. The door SWINGS opens. They've reached SWI ARM 9, which leads to the white room and the command modu Neil grabs his oxygen tank and leads the others onto --

location: SWING ARM 9, LAUNCH PAD 39A, CAPE CANAVERAL

text: Neil walks forward, eyes on the CAPSULE. Techs scurry, we hear chatter over comms, but it’s FAINT, SUBSUMED by the hiss of oxygen and Neil’s INTENSE FOCUS on the task ahead This is a solitary moment. Neil barely noticing as a tech walks up to help him with his oxygen tank. Neil hands his tank to the tech, blinks... the tech looks like ELLIOT. Neil turns away... and spots a_tech who looks like ED. Neil pauses. PUSH IN on his face, his eyes... as he CLOSE them. The HISSING grows louder and we PRELAP FAINT COMMS
The leaky hydrogen valve on the 200 foot level shouldn’t be a problem...
Neil. Eyes closed. T minus 2 hours 10 minutes
We’re powering up the console now.  119. His eyes BLINK OPEN as the lights on the console FLASH ON Neil’s strapped into the capsule. Buzz and Mike beside hi
Console on. We’re go to close up. The techs move to close the hatch but Deke leans in.
Give me a second. (to Neil, COMMS) .--We thought about a pill but we realized if the landing goes south and you get stranded you can just...
Purge the suits, go to sleep. Neil’s thought it through, he isn’t fazed at all. Deke reacts. SURPRISINGLY EMOTIONAL, he GRABS Neil’s gloved ha

Make us proud. Deke exits. The techs move in to close the hatch, COVERIN the front window with a PROTECTIVE SHIELD. We HOLD ON the three men in the tight, CLAUSTROPHOBIC cabin. An odd quiet. Eerily punctuated by a loud HISS.
